channel.title: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?
channel.description:
Today I wanted to burn Yes Man to a dvd so I can watch it tonight. So I start ashampoo, and select "burn a movie from a prepared folder". That's what I always do. But it fails to do so. It comes up with a media error, which I can fix by using a different brand of dvds, using a lower burning speed (Doh!, on my laptop the max is 2x), updating my firmware etc... So after having to throw away 3 dvd's I decide to try and burn it as a data disc. I use the same prepared folder (containing .vob files) and it works!
So I'm wondering: what's the difference between burning it as a movie disc and as a data disc?

item.title: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

So my problem lies in the fact that somehow the burning software fucks up the formatting? I tried it on my laptop and my desktop, and both gave me the same error.

Oh well, I got to see Yes Man, so my night wasn’t wasted completely.

Read full topic
item.source: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?

item.title: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

DVD Movie Discs are transcoded video (avi/mpeg/wmv) -> NTSC or PAL.

Read full topic
item.source: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?

item.title: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

A movie disc you can watch on a DVD player and whatnot, with a data disc, all if does is burn the source files on it, it doesn’t format the disc so you can watch it on your TV or other devices.

Read full topic
item.source: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?

item.title: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Your DVD Player is oviously pretty good and can read data disc’s while older appliances can only play movie disk.
Data Disks keep the movie in files while Movie disks are written so the laser can easily read the movie in sequence like a record player (accept a bit more complicated)

Read full topic
item.source: What's the difference between burning as a movie/data disc?
